newsitem.title: MALI: Mali opts for April legislative election.
newsitem.headline: Mali opts for April legislative election.

text.p: Mali will hold parliamentary elections on April 13, over a month later than planned, state television reported, quoting a letter from its prime minister to the head of the independent electoral commission.
The second round of the elections, which will kick off Mali's second multi-party national elections, would take place on April 27, it added late on Friday.
The Independent National Electoral Commission CENI had requested that the elections be put back from March 9 and March 23, citing organisational delays.
Presidential elections will take place as originally planned on May 4 and 18, municipal elections on June 1.
President Alpha Oumar Konare, a historian, won a five-year term in Mali's widely praised 1992 democratic transition and is seeking a second term.
His supporters, grouped in the Alliance for Democracy in Mali or ADEMA, had a majority in the old 116-seat national assembly. The new assembly will have 147 seats.
There are two main opposition alliances, the Rally of Patriotic Forces (RFP) and Front for Change and Democracy (FCD).

Thirteen opposition deputes placed a motion of no confidence before parliament, accusing the government of being unable to organise elections within the constitutional deadline. Parliament rejected the motion on Tuesday.
Parliament's mandate ends on April 17, Konare's on June 8.
Mali's last elections followed the 1991 overthrow of dictator Moussa Traore by soldiers, led by General Amadou Toumani Toure, who ushered in civilian rule and stepped down.
